name: Tyler W
comment info:
1. Hip-Hop predominantly makes its sales through online streaming because of the people that listen to that genre of music. The main audience of Hip-Hop is the youth, who have moved away from physical sales and onto online sales. This will inevitably lead to the end of the traditional market as this youthful generation will take the place of the old, pushing away their ideals and implementing their own. The question is whether this phenomenon will make a positive or negative impact and if it will affect our everyday lives in the near future.

2. Something interesting that I've noticed is how many rappers are on the streaming list but almost none on the traditional sales list. This lets me look at the differences between these artists and why. Eminem, in particular, makes his appearance only in the list of traditional sales and Drake only makes his on online streaming. This demonstrates the difference in the audience, especially their age. Drake obviously appeals to a much younger generation that Eminem's, who hit his prime arguably in the early 2000s, while Drake is the top today. The youth are leading the frontier of the music industry and will inevitably lead to online streaming taking over altogether.

name: Moderator Bill Gottschalk

Thanks to all students who responded. name: Hannah K
comment info:
The graph above displays how individuals consumed music in 2018 according to genre. It juxtaposes traditional sales of music, being sales and radio play, with both traditional sales and streaming. For exclusively traditional sales, I notice that the genre of music listened to/purchased was dispersed relatively evenly, with R&B/Hip-Hop at 20%, Pop at 23%, Rock at 33% and country at 14%. However, I noticed that for traditional sales coupled with streaming, the distribution is more uneven; R&B/Hip-Hop takes the lead at 54%, followed by Pop at 19%, Rock at 13%, and country at 9.5%. I think the disparity in music consumption is due to different listeners. Streaming is a new way of listening to music, and is thus largely embraced by predominantly younger audiences. Younger people, such as teenagers much like myself, tend to gravitate towards R&B/Hip-Hop. Contrairly, older listeners typically aren’t as “with the times” and tech savvy, so they often enjoy music how they always have -- through traditional sales of purchasing, for instance, CDs, as opposed to streaming online. I think that it is because younger people tend to stream and listen to R&B/Hip-Hop that the music consumption differs widely. Plus, depending on how much music one listens to, streaming can also be more cost effective regardless of age. I wonder what the white boxes toward the end of the bars account for? 

Title: Millennials and Music: Streaming is the Next Big Thing

name: Ava D.
comment info:
Are your music preferences based on the lyrics or the beat of the songs you listen to? This question, is one I have for those who prefer Hip-Hop music to other genres such as Country. It seems that music preference has shifted from quality of the words being said, to the beat that the lyrics are set to. As an avid listener of country music, I can honestly say that I appreciate this genre for the lyrics and wholesome messages that it portrays. But, I can say that the beat of the song can ruin the entire message. With this being said, I can see why music has shifted from content of the message to the beat itself. While I do enjoy listening to "Mo Bamba," I do not find much quality in the song other than the beat it is set to. Music preference has shifted through the years, and in today's society, music is being streamed and listened to based on the way it sounds. Since electronics have played a large part in music, the sounds and beats are those that could have never been produced 20 years ago. For this reason, I feel that people are choosing to listen to what is ~new and different.~ 

With apps such as Spotify and Apple Music, it comes as no surprise to me that the consumption percentages are what they are. Younger consumers, especially teenagers, are turning to Apple Music and Spotify to listen to their favorite songs without actually purchasing them. Paying $10 a month to stream unlimited amounts of music makes much more sense than paying for each individual download.

replies.comment info: Greetings @Ava D.!  I have to agree with you about the lyrics and beats.  I enjoy the lyrics of Christian music, but I am an avid EDM (electronic dance music) fan due to the beat of the music.  You brought up a good point that you can sample many genres of music with an unlimited streaming service to decide what type of music really interests you.  Do you have a catchy headline that could be used?

Hello Miss Ava Daley.  I as well enjoy a good Mo Bamba but don't really find quality to the lyrics. I think you made a good point here saying preference has changed from lyrics to beat. Do you think this is a bad thing?

name: Mia D.
comment info:
This graph does not surprise me in the slightest. Technological streaming have completely overtaken traditional CD sales. In a way, this saddens me. There was nothing better than jamming out to Taylor Swift on my Hello Kitty CD player. However, even more-so, I am amazed. It is astonishing that people are now able to play music at the tap of a finger.
In regards to the percentages, it is no shock to me that rap music consusmes more than half of the total. If you look at the Billboard Top-100, you will see that most of the songs are by rappers, such as Travis Scott, A-Boogie-Wit-Da-Hoodie, and Drake. I feel that this high percentage may be a contributing factor as to why violent is so prevalent in society today. A lot of these songs discuss murder, gangs, etc. If people are constantly listening to this, it's not going to inspire them to establish world peace. However, I can't say I'm not a fan of rap!
It's interesting that traditional sales are pretty much evenly distributed among genres. Rock has more sales than rap and pop (which are typically favorites of the younger crowd). This leads me to infer that it is primarily an older crowd who is still purchasing CDs, perhaps due to the fact that they've grown up on it and it's what they're used to.

replies.comment info: Good morning @Mia D.!  Great wondering at the end of your comment about the age variable that might explain why some people still insist on purchasing CD’s today.  Technology can be a scary thing for us old folks!  Please come back tomorrow to see the big reveal!

comment info: Wow, this graph truly speaks to me. As a middle schooler, I had always enjoyed pop and country music. I would purchase songs and CD's from iTunes. comment info: I think that this graph speaks greatly to the audience that listens to Hip Hop and R&B music. The genres that are acquired through the variety of selling methods speaks to the generations listening to each genre.
